sunchao commented on pull request #9409:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9409#issuecomment-773490122


   > Calling mem::forget on the Vec<Box<dyn ArrayBuilder>> prevents the vector's destructor from running.
   
   Hmm isn't that the purpose? 
   ```rust
           let builders = std::mem::replace(&mut self.field_builders, Vec::new());
           std::mem::forget(builders);
   ```
   the `builders` is forgotten here but the destructor for `self.field_any` will still be invoked right? 


----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

sfackler commented on pull request #9409:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9409#issuecomment-773492740


   field_any does not free the memory used for builders's vector. It does free the builders themselves, but that is a separate thing.


----------------------------------------------------------------

sunchao commented on pull request #9409:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9409#issuecomment-773494502


   yeah you're right - the `builders` still carries the memory allocated for the original `field_builders` vec which will leak.

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
The StructBuilder stores two copies of the inner ArrayBuilders in two separate Vecs via some unsafe code. To avoid double-dropping the builders, the StructBuilder Drop impl uses mem::forget on one of the vectors. This avoids calling the destructor of the ArrayBuilders twice, but also leaks the memory of the Vec itself.

In addition, the double-vecs with the unsafe code is completely unnecessary since you can just call `ArrayBuilder::as_mut_any` on the `dyn ArrayBuilder` instead of having to covert to a `Box<dyn Any>`.
